parts:
Below are 15 **challenging** kinematics problems modelled on the style of **Exercise 18.1, 18.2, and Revision Exercise 18** in your attached chapter. fileciteturn0file0  
(Notation: displacement \(s\) in m, velocity \(v\) in m/s, acceleration \(a\) in m/s\(^2\); \(t\) in s unless stated.)

---

## 1) Polynomial \(s(t)\), return to \(O\), distance vs displacement
A particle moves in a straight line so that, \(t\) seconds after passing \(O\),  
\[
s=t^3-12t^2+36t.
\]
(i) Find \(v\) and \(a\).  
(ii) Find the times when the particle is at rest and the corresponding positions.  
(iii) Find the total distance travelled from \(t=0\) until it first returns to \(O\).  
(iv) Find the average speed over that time.

**Solution (concise):**  
\(v=3t^2-24t+36=3(t-2)(t-6)\), \(a=6t-24\).  
Rest at \(t=2,6\); \(s(2)=32\), \(s(6)=0\).  
First return to \(O\): \(t=6\). Distance \(=32+32=64\) m.  
Average speed \(=64/6=32/3\approx10.67\) m/s.

---

## 2) Factorable quartic \(s(t)\): multiple rests, crossing vs touching \(O\)
A particle moves so that
\[
s=\frac14 t^4-\frac{11}{3}t^3+17t^2-24t,\quad t\ge0.
\]
(i) Find \(v\) and factorise it fully.  
(ii) Hence find all \(t\) when the particle is at rest.  
(iii) Find all \(t>0\) when the particle is at \(O\), and state whether it **crosses** \(O\) or only **touches** \(O\).  
(iv) Find the total distance travelled in the first \(6\) seconds.

**Solution:**  
\(v=s'=(t-1)(t-4)(t-6)\). So rest at \(t=1,4,6\).  
\(s= \dfrac{t(t-6)^2(3t-8)}{12}\Rightarrow s=0\) at \(t=\frac83\) and \(t=6\).  
At \(t=\frac83\), \(v>0\) so it **crosses** \(O\). At \(t=6\), \((t-6)^2\) ⇒ it **touches** \(O\) (no sign change in \(s\)).  
Distance \(0\to6\): \( \frac{125}{12}+\frac{63}{4}+\frac{16}{3}=\frac{63}{2}=31.5\) m.

---

## 3) Given \(v(t)\): direction changes + total distance (with surds)
A particle passes \(O\) at \(t=0\) and has velocity
\[
v=t^2-6t+5.
\]
(i) Find \(s\) in terms of \(t\).  
(ii) Find the times when it is at rest.  
(iii) Find the first two times \(t>0\) when it is at \(O\).  
(iv) Find the total distance travelled in the first \(8\) seconds.

**Solution:**  
\(s=\int v\,dt=\frac13t^3-3t^2+5t\) (using \(s(0)=0\)).  
Rest: \(v=(t-1)(t-5)=0\Rightarrow t=1,5\).  
At \(O\): \(s=0\Rightarrow t=0,\ \frac{9\pm\sqrt{21}}{2}\) ⇒ \(t\approx2.209,\ 6.792\).  
Distance \(0\to8\): \(|s(1)-s(0)|+|s(5)-s(1)|+|s(8)-s(5)|=40\) m.

---

## 4) Given \(a(t)\) with exponential: minimum velocity (not maximum)
A particle has acceleration
\[
a=6-8e^{-t},\quad v(0)=2,\ s(0)=0.
\]
(i) Find \(v(t)\) and \(s(t)\).  
(ii) Find when \(a=0\).  
(iii) Hence find the **minimum** value of \(v\) and the displacement then.  
(iv) Does the particle ever come to rest?

**Solution:**  
\(v=6t+8e^{-t}-6\).  
\(s=3t^2-6t-8e^{-t}+8\).  
\(a=0\Rightarrow e^{-t}=\frac34\Rightarrow t=\ln\frac43\approx0.2877\).  
Minimum \(v=6\ln\frac43\approx1.726\) m/s; \(s=3(\ln\frac43)^2-6\ln\frac43+2\approx0.522\) m.  
No rest since \(v_{\min}>0\).

---

## 5) Trig \(a(t)\): rest times + distance over \(0\le t\le 2\pi\)
A particle satisfies
\[
a=-4\sin t+3\cos t,\quad v(0)=1,\ s(0)=0.
\]
(i) Find \(v\) and \(s\).  
(ii) Show the first time it is at rest is \(t=\frac{\pi}{2}\).  
(iii) Find \(s\) and \(a\) at \(t=\frac{\pi}{2}\).  
(iv) Find the total distance travelled for \(0\le t\le 2\pi\).

**Solution:**  
\(v=4\cos t+3\sin t-3\).  
\(s=4\sin t-3\cos t-3t+3\).  
\(v=0\Rightarrow 4\cos t+3\sin t=3\Rightarrow t=\frac{\pi}{2}\) is the first positive solution.  
\(s(\pi/2)=7-\frac{3\pi}{2}\approx2.288\) m; \(a(\pi/2)=-4\) m/s\(^2\).  
Total distance \(=16+12\arctan\!\frac34\approx23.72\) m.

---

## 6) Linear \(a=6t-k\): determine parameter + distance between rest points
A particle passes \(O\) with velocity \(5\) m/s and has
\[
a=6t-k.
\]
Given \(v(2)=-7\) m/s:  
(i) Find \(k\).  
(ii) Find all times when the particle is at rest.  
(iii) Find the distance between the two rest positions.

**Solution:**  
\(v=3t^2-kt+5\). Use \(v(2)=-7\): \(12-2k+5=-7\Rightarrow k=12\).  
Rest: \(3t^2-12t+5=0\Rightarrow t=\frac{6\pm\sqrt{21}}{3}\approx0.472,\ 3.528\).  
\(s=t^3-6t^2+5t\). Distance between rest positions \(=\frac{28}{9}\sqrt{21}\approx14.26\) m.

---

## 7) Piecewise \(a(t)\): join conditions + distance with reversal
A particle passes \(O\) with velocity \(4\) m/s. Its acceleration is
\[
a=\begin{cases}
12-3t, & 0\le t\le 4,\\
-8, & t>4.
\end{cases}
\]
(i) Find \(v(t)\) for \(0\le t\le 4\).  
(ii) Find \(v(t)\) for \(t>4\).  
(iii) Find the first time the particle comes to rest.  
(iv) Find the total distance travelled in the first \(8\) seconds.

**Solution:**  
For \(0\le t\le4\): \(v=4+12t-\tfrac32 t^2\); \(s=4t+6t^2-\tfrac12 t^3\).  
At \(t=4\): \(v(4)=28\), \(s(4)=80\).  
For \(t>4\): \(v=28-8(t-4)=60-8t\); \(s=80+\int_4^t(60-8u)\,du=60t-4t^2-96\).  
Rest: \(60-8t=0\Rightarrow t=\tfrac{15}{2}=7.5\) s, \(s=129\) m.  
At \(t=8\), \(s=128\) m ⇒ distance \(=129+1=130\) m.

---

## 8) Exponential \(a(t)\) to a stopping point: time, distance, average speed
A particle passes \(O\) with speed \(18\) m/s and has
\[
a=-9e^{-0.3t},\quad s(0)=0.
\]
It comes to rest at point \(P\).  
(i) Find the time to reach \(P\).  
(ii) Find \(OP\).  
(iii) Find the average speed during the first \(6\) seconds.

**Solution:**  
\(v=30e^{-0.3t}-12\). Rest: \(30e^{-0.3t}=12\Rightarrow t_P=\frac{10}{3}\ln\frac52\approx3.054\) s.  
\(s=100(1-e^{-0.3t})-12t\). So \(OP=s(t_P)=60-40\ln\frac52\approx23.35\) m.  
\(s(6)=100(1-e^{-1.8})-72=28-100e^{-1.8}\approx11.47\) m.  
Distance in first 6 s \(=2OP-s(6)\approx35.23\) m ⇒ average speed \(\approx 35.23/6=5.87\) m/s.

---

## 9) Two particles: meet twice (because both reverse)
Two particles \(P\) and \(Q\) move on a line with \(A\) and \(B\) \(30\) m apart. Take direction \(A\to B\) as positive.  
At \(t=0\), \(P\) passes \(A\) with \(v_P=10-2t\).  
At \(t=0\), \(Q\) passes \(B\) with \(v_Q=t-6\).  
(i) Find the two times when \(P\) and \(Q\) meet.  
(ii) Find the distances of the meeting points from \(A\).  
(iii) Find the relative speed at the first meeting.

**Solution:**  
\(x_P=10t-t^2\), \(x_Q=30+\tfrac12 t^2-6t\).  
Meet: \(3t^2-32t+60=0\Rightarrow t=\dfrac{16\pm2\sqrt{19}}{3}\approx2.428,\ 8.239\) s.  
Positions from \(A\): \(x=\dfrac{148\pm4\sqrt{19}}{9}\approx18.38\text{ m},\ 14.51\text{ m}\).  
Relative speed at first meeting \(=v_P-v_Q=2\sqrt{19}\approx8.72\) m/s.

---

## 10) Two particles from \(O\): three meetings, one at rest
Particles \(P\) and \(Q\) move from \(O\) with displacements
\[
s_P=t^3-6t^2+9t,\qquad s_Q=4t.
\]
(i) Find all times \(t\ge0\) when they are at the same position.  
(ii) Find \(v_P\) at those times and state when \(P\) is instantaneously at rest at the meeting.  
(iii) Find the total distance travelled by \(P\) in the first \(5\) seconds.

**Solution:**  
Meet: \(t^3-6t^2+9t=4t\Rightarrow t(t^2-6t+5)=0\Rightarrow t=0,1,5\).  
\(v_P=3t^2-12t+9=3(t-1)(t-3)\). So at \(t=1\), \(v_P=0\) (meeting at rest).  
\(s_P(0)=0,\ s_P(1)=4,\ s_P(3)=0,\ s_P(5)=20\). Distance \(=4+4+20=28\) m.

---

## 11) Vertical motion: determine \(u\) from impact time
A particle is projected vertically upwards from a platform \(30\) m above the ground. Take \(g=9.8\) m/s\(^2\). It hits the ground \(5\) s later.  
(i) Find the initial velocity \(u\).  
(ii) Find the maximum height above the ground.  
(iii) Find the speed on impact.

**Solution:**  
Height \(s=30+ut-4.9t^2\). Set \(s(5)=0\): \(30+5u-122.5=0\Rightarrow u=18.5\) m/s.  
Max height \(=30+\dfrac{u^2}{2g}=30+\dfrac{18.5^2}{19.6}\approx47.46\) m.  
Impact velocity \(v(5)=u-9.8(5)=18.5-49=-30.5\) ⇒ speed \(30.5\) m/s.

---

## 12) Simple harmonic motion: amplitude/period + first origin-crossing with \(v>0\)
A particle undergoes simple harmonic motion with displacement
\[
x=6\cos 2t+8\sin 2t.
\]
(i) Find the amplitude and period.  
(ii) Find the first time \(t>0\) when it passes through the origin with **positive** velocity.  
(iii) Find the maximum speed.  
(iv) Find the acceleration when it first comes to rest after \(t=0\).

**Solution:**  
Amplitude \(=\sqrt{6^2+8^2}=10\) m; period \(=\dfrac{2\pi}{2}=\pi\) s.  
Write \(x=10\sin(2t+\beta)\) where \(\beta=\arctan\!\frac34\).  
Origin with \(v>0\): \(2t+\beta=2\pi\Rightarrow t=\pi-\beta/2\approx2.820\) s.  
Max speed \(=\omega A=2(10)=20\) m/s.  
First rest: \(v=0\Rightarrow 2t+\beta=\pi/2\Rightarrow t=\pi/4-\beta/2\approx0.4636\) s; then \(x=10\Rightarrow a=-\omega^2x=-4(10)=-40\) m/s\(^2\).

---

## 13) “Distance in the fourth second” with direction change inside the second
A particle passes \(O\) at \(t=0\) with velocity
\[
v=t^2-5t+5.
\]
(i) Find when the particle is at rest.  
(ii) Find the distance travelled in the **fourth second** (i.e. from \(t=3\) to \(t=4\)).

**Solution:**  
Rest: \(t=\dfrac{5\pm\sqrt5}{2}\) (the larger root \(\approx3.618\) lies in \((3,4)\)).  
\(s=\frac13t^3-\frac52 t^2+5t\), so  
distance in 4th second \(= (s(3)-s(t_r))+(s(4)-s(t_r))=\dfrac{5\sqrt5-8}{6}\approx0.529\) m.

---

## 14) Velocity with \(\ln\) (from integrating \(\frac{1}{t+1}\)), no \(\int \ln\)
A particle passes \(O\) at \(t=0\) with velocity
\[
v=2-\frac{3}{t+1},\quad t\ge0.
\]
(i) Find \(a(t)\).  
(ii) Find \(s(t)\) given \(s(0)=0\).  
(iii) Find the time when the particle is at rest.  
(iv) Find the total distance travelled in the first \(1\) second.

**Solution:**  
\(a=v'=\dfrac{3}{(t+1)^2}\).  
\(s=\int v\,dt=2t-3\ln(t+1)\) (since \(s(0)=0\)).  
Rest: \(2-\dfrac{3}{t+1}=0\Rightarrow t=\tfrac12\) s.  
Distance \(0\to1\): turning at \(t=\tfrac12\), so  
\[
D=\bigl|s(\tfrac12)\bigr|+\bigl(s(1)-s(\tfrac12)\bigr)=6\ln 3-9\ln 2\approx0.351\text{ m}.
\]

---

## 15) Train (speed–time quadratic): distance, max speed, “above threshold” distance
A train leaves station \(P\) and later stops at station \(Q\). Its speed \(v\) (km/h) after \(t\) hours is
\[
v=240t-60t^2,\quad t\ge0.
\]
(i) Find the time taken to travel from \(P\) to \(Q\).  
(ii) Find the distance \(PQ\).  
(iii) Find the maximum speed and when it occurs.  
(iv) Find the distance travelled while \(v>180\) km/h.

**Solution:**  
Stop when \(v=0\Rightarrow t(240-60t)=0\Rightarrow t=4\) h.  
Distance \(=\int_0^4(240t-60t^2)\,dt=[120t^2-20t^3]_0^4=640\) km.  
Max at vertex \(t=2\): \(v_{\max}=240(2)-60(4)=240\) km/h.  
\(v>180\Rightarrow 240t-60t^2>180\Rightarrow t\in(1,3)\).  
Distance \(=\int_1^3(240t-60t^2)\,dt=[120t^2-20t^3]_1^3=440\) km.

Here are **replacements** for **Q(7), Q(11), Q(12)** that satisfy your constraints. (All other questions remain unchanged.)

## Revised Q(7) (no piecewise functions)

A particle travels in a straight line so that, \(t\) seconds after passing a fixed point \(O\), its **velocity** \(v\) m/s is
\[
v=-(t-1)(t-5)(t-8),\qquad s(0)=0.
\]
(i) Find the acceleration \(a\) in terms of \(t\).  
(ii) Find the displacement \(s\) in terms of \(t\).  
(iii) Find the values of \(t\) when the particle is instantaneously at rest, and state the intervals of \(t\) for which the particle moves in the positive direction.  
(iv) Find the **total distance travelled** in the first \(8\) seconds.

**Concise solution:**  
Expand: \(v=-t^{3}+14t^{2}-53t+40\).  
(i) \(a=\dfrac{dv}{dt}=-3t^{2}+28t-53.\)  
(ii) \(s=\int v\,dt=-\dfrac14 t^{4}+\dfrac{14}{3}t^{3}-\dfrac{53}{2}t^{2}+40t\) (since \(s(0)=0\)).  
(iii) Rest when \(v=0\Rightarrow t=1,5,8\). Direction: \(v>0\) on \((0,1)\cup(5,8)\), and \(v<0\) on \((1,5)\).  
(iv) \(s(1)=\frac{215}{12},\ s(5)=-\frac{425}{12},\ s(8)=-\frac{32}{3}\).  
Distance \(= \left|s(1)-s(0)\right|+\left|s(5)-s(1)\right|+\left|s(8)-s(5)\right|=96\ \text{m}.\)

---

## Revised Q(11) (horizontal motion only; no \(g\))

A particle moves along a straight line with displacement \(s\) metres measured from a fixed point \(O\) (positive away from \(O\)). Its acceleration is **constant**
\[
a=-6\ \text{m/s}^2.
\]
At \(t=0\), the particle is at point \(A\) where \(s=30\), and it is moving **away** from \(O\) with speed \(u\) m/s. It passes through \(O\) at \(t=5\).

(i) Find \(u\).  
(ii) Find the time when the particle is furthest from \(O\), and that maximum value of \(s\).  
(iii) Find the speed when it passes through \(O\).  
(iv) Find the time when it next passes through \(A\) (i.e. when \(s=30\) again for \(t>0\)).

**Concise solution:**  
Since \(a=\dfrac{dv}{dt}=-6\),  
\(v=u-6t\), and \(s=30+\int_0^t (u-6\tau)\,d\tau=30+ut-3t^2\).  
Given \(s(5)=0\): \(0=30+5u-75\Rightarrow u=9\ \text{m/s}.\)  
(ii) Furthest from \(O\) when \(v=0\Rightarrow 9-6t=0\Rightarrow t=\frac32\) s.  
Then \(s_{\max}=30+9\cdot\frac32-3\left(\frac32\right)^2=\frac{147}{4}=36.75\) m.  
(iii) \(v(5)=9-30=-21\Rightarrow\) speed \(=21\) m/s.  
(iv) \(s=30\Rightarrow 30+9t-3t^2=30\Rightarrow 3t(3-t)=0\Rightarrow t=3\) s.

---

## Revised Q(12) (no “SHM”; must use the R-formula)

A particle moves in a straight line so that its displacement \(x\) metres at time \(t\) seconds is
\[
x=6\cos 2t+8\sin 2t.
\]
(i) Using the **R-formula**, write \(x\) in the form
\[
x=R\sin(2t+\alpha),
\]
where \(R>0\) and \(\alpha\) is a **positive acute** angle (in radians).  
(ii) Hence state the **maximum** and **minimum** values of \(x\).  
(iii) Find the period of the motion.  
(iv) Find the first time \(t>0\) when \(x=0\) and \(\dfrac{dx}{dt}>0\).  
(v) Find the maximum value of the speed \(\left|\dfrac{dx}{dt}\right|\), and the acceleration when the particle first comes to rest for \(t>0\).

**Concise solution:**  
(i) Match \(R\sin(2t+\alpha)=R(\sin2t\cos\alpha+\cos2t\sin\alpha)\).  
So \(R\cos\alpha=8,\ R\sin\alpha=6\Rightarrow R=\sqrt{8^2+6^2}=10\), \(\alpha=\tan^{-1}\!\left(\frac{3}{4}\right)\) (acute).  
Thus \(x=10\sin(2t+\alpha)\).  
(ii) \(\max x=10,\ \min x=-10\).  
(iii) Period \(T=\pi\) (since \(\sin(2t+\alpha)\) repeats when \(2t\) increases by \(2\pi\)).  
(iv) \(x=0\Rightarrow 2t+\alpha=n\pi\). Also \(x' = 20\cos(2t+\alpha)\), so \(x'>0\Rightarrow \cos(n\pi)>0\Rightarrow n\) even. Smallest \(t>0\) is \(n=2\):  
\[
t=\frac{2\pi-\alpha}{2}=\pi-\frac{\alpha}{2}.
\]
(v) \(x'=20\cos(2t+\alpha)\Rightarrow \max|x'|=20\).  
First rest for \(t>0\): \(x'=0\Rightarrow 2t+\alpha=\frac{\pi}{2}\Rightarrow t=\frac{\pi}{4}-\frac{\alpha}{2}\).  
Acceleration \(x''=-40\sin(2t+\alpha)\), so at that time \(\sin(\pi/2)=1\Rightarrow x''=-40\ \text{m/s}^2.\)

---

```latex
\documentclass[11pt]{article}

\usepackage[a4paper,margin=1in]{geometry}
\usepackage{amsmath,amssymb}
\usepackage{multicol}
\usepackage{enumitem}

\setlength{\parindent}{0pt}
\setlength{\parskip}{6pt}

\title{\textbf{A Maths Kinematics Questions - Version 1}}
\date{}

\begin{document}
\maketitle

\textbf{Conventions.} Motion is along a straight line. Displacement is denoted by $s$ (or $x$) metres from a fixed origin, velocity by $v$ m/s, acceleration by $a$ m/s$^2$, and time by $t$ seconds unless stated otherwise.

\section*{Questions}

\begin{enumerate}[leftmargin=*,label=\textbf{Q\arabic*.}]

\item A particle moves in a straight line so that, $t$ seconds after passing $O$,
\[
s=t^3-12t^2+36t.
\]
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\roman*),leftmargin=*]
\item Find $v$ and $a$.
\item Find the times when the particle is at rest and the corresponding positions.
\item Find the total distance travelled from $t=0$ until it first returns to $O$.
\item Find the average speed over that time.
\end{enumerate}

\item A particle moves so that
\[
s=\frac14 t^4-\frac{11}{3}t^3+17t^2-24t,\quad t\ge0.
\]
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\roman*),leftmargin=*]
\item Find $v$ and factorise it fully.
\item Hence find all $t$ when the particle is at rest.
\item Find all $t>0$ when the particle is at $O$, and state whether it \emph{crosses} $O$ or only \emph{touches} $O$ at each such time.
\item Find the total distance travelled in the first $6$ seconds.
\end{enumerate}

\item A particle passes $O$ at $t=0$ and has velocity
\[
v=t^2-6t+5.
\]
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\roman*),leftmargin=*]
\item Find $s$ in terms of $t$.
\item Find the times when it is at rest.
\item Find the first two times $t>0$ when it is at $O$.
\item Find the total distance travelled in the first $8$ seconds.
\end{enumerate}

\item A particle has acceleration
\[
a=6-8e^{-t},\quad v(0)=2,\quad s(0)=0.
\]
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\roman*),leftmargin=*]
\item Find $v(t)$ and $s(t)$.
\item Find when $a=0$.
\item Hence find the minimum value of $v$ and the displacement then.
\item Does the particle ever come to rest?
\end{enumerate}

\item A particle satisfies
\[
a=-4\sin t+3\cos t,\quad v(0)=1,\quad s(0)=0.
\]
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\roman*),leftmargin=*]
\item Find $v$ and $s$.
\item Show the first time it is at rest is $t=\frac{\pi}{2}$.
\item Find $s$ and $a$ at $t=\frac{\pi}{2}$.
\item Find the total distance travelled for $0\le t\le 2\pi$.
\end{enumerate}

\item A particle passes $O$ with velocity $5$ m/s and has
\[
a=6t-k.
\]
Given that $v(2)=-7$ m/s:
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\roman*),leftmargin=*]
\item Find $k$.
\item Find all times when the particle is at rest.
\item Find the distance between the two rest positions.
\end{enumerate}

\item A particle travels in a straight line so that, $t$ seconds after passing a fixed point $O$, its velocity $v$ m/s is
\[
v=-(t-1)(t-5)(t-8),\qquad s(0)=0.
\]
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\roman*),leftmargin=*]
\item Find the acceleration $a$ in terms of $t$.
\item Find the displacement $s$ in terms of $t$.
\item Find the values of $t$ when the particle is instantaneously at rest, and state the intervals of $t$ for which the particle moves in the positive direction.
\item Find the total distance travelled in the first $8$ seconds.
\end{enumerate}

\item A particle passes $O$ with speed $18$ m/s and has
\[
a=-9e^{-\frac{3}{10}t},\quad s(0)=0.
\]
It comes to rest at a point $P$.
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\roman*),leftmargin=*]
\item Find the time taken to reach $P$.
\item Find $OP$.
\item Find the average speed during the first $6$ seconds.
\end{enumerate}

\item Two particles $P$ and $Q$ move on a straight line with fixed points $A$ and $B$ $30$ m apart. Take the direction $A\to B$ as positive.\\
At $t=0$, $P$ passes $A$ with velocity $v_P=10-2t$.\\
At $t=0$, $Q$ passes $B$ with velocity $v_Q=t-6$.
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\roman*),leftmargin=*]
\item Find the two times when $P$ and $Q$ meet.
\item Find the distances of the meeting points from $A$.
\item Find the relative speed at the first meeting.
\end{enumerate}

\item Two particles move from $O$ with displacements
\[
s_P=t^3-6t^2+9t,\qquad s_Q=4t.
\]
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\roman*),leftmargin=*]
\item Find all times $t\ge0$ when they are at the same position.
\item Find $v_P$ at those times and state when $P$ is instantaneously at rest at the meeting.
\item Find the total distance travelled by $P$ in the first $5$ seconds.
\end{enumerate}

\item A particle moves along a straight line with displacement $s$ metres measured from a fixed point $O$ (positive away from $O$). Its acceleration is constant
\[
a=-6\ \text{m/s}^2.
\]
At $t=0$, the particle is at point $A$ where $s=30$, and it is moving away from $O$ with speed $u$ m/s. It passes through $O$ at $t=5$.
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\roman*),leftmargin=*]
\item Find $u$.
\item Find the time when the particle is furthest from $O$, and that maximum value of $s$.
\item Find the speed when it passes through $O$.
\item Find the time when it next passes through $A$ (i.e.\ when $s=30$ again for $t>0$).
\end{enumerate}

\item A particle moves in a straight line so that its displacement $x$ metres at time $t$ seconds is
\[
x=6\cos 2t+8\sin 2t.
\]
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\roman*),leftmargin=*]
\item Using the R-formula, write $x$ in the form $x=R\sin(2t+\alpha)$ where $R>0$ and $\alpha$ is a positive acute angle (in radians).
\item Hence state the maximum and minimum values of $x$.
\item Find the period of the motion.
\item Find the first time $t>0$ when $x=0$ and $\dfrac{dx}{dt}>0$.
\item Find the maximum speed, and the acceleration when the particle first comes to rest for $t>0$.
\end{enumerate}

\item A particle passes $O$ at $t=0$ with velocity
\[
v=t^2-5t+5.
\]
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\roman*),leftmargin=*]
\item Find when the particle is at rest.
\item Find the distance travelled in the fourth second (i.e.\ from $t=3$ to $t=4$).
\end{enumerate}

\item A particle passes $O$ at $t=0$ with velocity
\[
v=2-\frac{3}{t+1},\quad t\ge0,\qquad s(0)=0.
\]
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\roman*),leftmargin=*]
\item Find $a(t)$.
\item Find $s(t)$.
\item Find the time when the particle is at rest.
\item Find the total distance travelled in the first $1$ second.
\end{enumerate}

\item A train leaves station $P$ and later stops at station $Q$. Its speed $v$ (km/h) after $t$ hours is
\[
v=240t-60t^2,\quad t\ge0.
\]
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\roman*),leftmargin=*]
\item Find the time taken to travel from $P$ to $Q$.
\item Find the distance $PQ$.
\item Find the maximum speed and when it occurs.
\item Find the distance travelled while $v>180$ km/h.
\end{enumerate}

\end{enumerate}

\newpage
\section*{Solutions}

\begin{multicols}{2}
\footnotesize

\begin{enumerate}[leftmargin=*,label=\textbf{Q\arabic*.}]

\item
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\roman*),leftmargin=*]
\item $v=3t^2-24t+36=3(t-2)(t-6)$, \quad $a=6t-24$.
\item Rest at $t=2,6$; $s(2)=32$, $s(6)=0$.
\item First return to $O$ at $t=6$. Distance $=32+32=64$ m.
\item Average speed $=64/6=32/3$ m/s.
\end{enumerate}

\item
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\roman*),leftmargin=*]
\item $v=s'=(t-1)(t-4)(t-6)$.
\item Rest at $t=1,4,6$.
\item $s=\dfrac{t(t-6)^2(3t-8)}{12}$, so $s=0$ at $t=\dfrac{8}{3}$ and $t=6$. At $t=\dfrac{8}{3}$ it crosses $O$; at $t=6$ it touches $O$.
\item Distance $0\to6$: $\dfrac{125}{12}+\dfrac{63}{4}+\dfrac{16}{3}=\dfrac{63}{2}$ m.
\end{enumerate}

\item
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\roman*),leftmargin=*]
\item $s=\int v\,dt=\dfrac13t^3-3t^2+5t$.
\item Rest: $v=(t-1)(t-5)=0\Rightarrow t=1,5$.
\item $s=0\Rightarrow t=0,\ \dfrac{9\pm\sqrt{21}}{2}$.
\item Distance $0\to8$: $|s(1)-s(0)|+|s(5)-s(1)|+|s(8)-s(5)|=40$ m.
\end{enumerate}

\item
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\roman*),leftmargin=*]
\item $v=6t+8e^{-t}-6$,\quad $s=3t^2-6t-8e^{-t}+8$.
\item $a=0\Rightarrow e^{-t}=\dfrac34\Rightarrow t=\ln\!\dfrac43$.
\item Minimum $v=6\ln\!\dfrac43$; at this time $s=3(\ln\!\frac43)^2-6\ln\!\frac43+2$.
\item No; $v_{\min}>0$.
\end{enumerate}

\item
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\roman*),leftmargin=*]
\item $v=4\cos t+3\sin t-3$, \quad $s=4\sin t-3\cos t-3t+3$.
\item First rest at $t=\dfrac{\pi}{2}$.
\item $s(\pi/2)=7-\dfrac{3\pi}{2}$,\quad $a(\pi/2)=-4$.
\item Total distance $=16+12\tan^{-1}\!\left(\dfrac{3}{4}\right)$ m $\approx23.72$ m.
\end{enumerate}

\item
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\roman*),leftmargin=*]
\item $v=3t^2-kt+5$. Use $v(2)=-7$: $12-2k+5=-7\Rightarrow k=12$.
\item Rest: $3t^2-12t+5=0\Rightarrow t=\dfrac{6\pm\sqrt{21}}{3}$.
\item $s=t^3-6t^2+5t$. Distance between rest positions $=\dfrac{28}{9}\sqrt{21}$ m.
\end{enumerate}

\item
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\roman*),leftmargin=*]
\item $a=\dfrac{dv}{dt}=-3t^{2}+28t-53$.
\item $s=\int v\,dt=-\dfrac14 t^{4}+\dfrac{14}{3}t^{3}-\dfrac{53}{2}t^{2}+40t$.
\item Rest at $t=1,5,8$. $v>0$ on $(0,1)\cup(5,8)$ and $v<0$ on $(1,5)$.
\item $s(1)=\dfrac{215}{12}$, $s(5)=-\dfrac{425}{12}$, $s(8)=-\dfrac{32}{3}$. Distance $=96$ m.
\end{enumerate}

\item
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\roman*),leftmargin=*]
\item $v=30e^{-\frac{3}{10}t}-12$. Rest: $30e^{-\frac{3}{10}t}=12\Rightarrow t=\dfrac{10}{3}\ln\!\dfrac52$.
\item $s=100(1-e^{-\frac{3}{10}t})-12t$, so $OP=60-40\ln\!\dfrac52$ m.
\item $s(6)=28-100e^{-1.8}$. Distance in first $6$ s $=2OP-s(6)$, so average speed $=\dfrac{2OP-s(6)}{6}\approx5.87$ m/s.
\end{enumerate}

\item
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\roman*),leftmargin=*]
\item $x_P=10t-t^2$, $x_Q=30+\dfrac12 t^2-6t$. Meet: $3t^2-32t+60=0$, so $t=\dfrac{16\pm2\sqrt{19}}{3}$.
\item Positions from $A$: $x=10t-t^2=\dfrac{148\pm4\sqrt{19}}{9}$ m.
\item Relative speed at first meeting: $v_P-v_Q=(10-2t)-(t-6)=16-3t=2\sqrt{19}$ m/s.
\end{enumerate}

\item
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\roman*),leftmargin=*]
\item $s_P=s_Q\Rightarrow t^3-6t^2+9t=4t\Rightarrow t=0,1,5$.
\item $v_P=3t^2-12t+9=3(t-1)(t-3)$; at $t=1$, $v_P=0$.
\item $s_P(0)=0$, $s_P(1)=4$, $s_P(3)=0$, $s_P(5)=20$. Distance $=4+4+20=28$ m.
\end{enumerate}

\item
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\roman*),leftmargin=*]
\item $v=u-6t$, $s=30+ut-3t^2$. Given $s(5)=0$: $30+5u-75=0\Rightarrow u=9$.
\item Furthest when $v=0$: $9-6t=0\Rightarrow t=\dfrac32$; $s_{\max}=\dfrac{147}{4}$ m.
\item $v(5)=9-30=-21$, speed $=21$ m/s.
\item $s=30\Rightarrow 30+9t-3t^2=30\Rightarrow t=3$ s.
\end{enumerate}

\item
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\roman*),leftmargin=*]
\item Compare $R\sin(2t+\alpha)=R(\sin2t\cos\alpha+\cos2t\sin\alpha)$ with $8\sin2t+6\cos2t$. Then $R\cos\alpha=8$, $R\sin\alpha=6$, so $R=10$ and $\alpha=\tan^{-1}\!\left(\dfrac{3}{4}\right)$.
\item $\max x=10$, $\min x=-10$.
\item Period $T=\pi$.
\item $x=0\Rightarrow 2t+\alpha=n\pi$ and $x'=20\cos(2t+\alpha)>0\Rightarrow n$ even. Smallest $t>0$: $t=\pi-\dfrac{\alpha}{2}$.

\[
(s(3)-s(t_r))+(s(4)-s(t_r))=\frac{5\sqrt5-8}{6}\ \text{m}.
\]
\end{enumerate}

\item
\begin{enumerate}[label=(\roman*),leftmargin=*]
\item $a=v'=\dfrac{3}{(t+1)^2}$.

\end{enumerate}

\end{enumerate}

\end{enumerate}

\end{multicols}
```

parts:
Here is **another set of 15 difficult kinematics questions (Version 2)**, designed to match the chapter’s style (mix of “find \(v,a\)”, “rest/turning points”, “distance in the \(n\)th second”, “range where \(v<0\)”, “use a sketch”, parameter-finding, etc.), with **more multi-particle** items and **more “average speed”** asks.

(Throughout: motion is along a straight line; displacement from \(O\) is \(s\) or \(x\); velocity \(v=\dfrac{ds}{dt}\); acceleration \(a=\dfrac{dv}{dt}\).)

---

## Q1  (given \(a\), integrate; turning points; average speed)
A particle passes through \(O\) at \(t=0\) with velocity \(30\) m/s. Its acceleration is
\[
a=6t-21.
\]
(i) Find \(v\) and \(s\).  
(ii) Find the times when the particle is instantaneously at rest.  
(iii) Find the distance between the two rest positions.  
(iv) Find the total distance travelled in the first \(6\) seconds and hence the average speed.  
(v) Describe the motion at \(t=4\) (direction of motion, and whether it is accelerating or decelerating).

**Solution (concise):**  
\(v=3t^2-21t+30=3(t-2)(t-5)\).  
\(s=t^3-\frac{21}{2}t^2+30t\) (since \(s(0)=0\)).  
Rest at \(t=2,5\). Positions: \(s(2)=26,\ s(5)=\frac{25}{2}\). Distance between rest positions \(=\frac{27}{2}=13.5\) m.  
\(s(6)=18\). Total distance \(=26+(26-\frac{25}{2})+(18-\frac{25}{2})=45\) m, average speed \(=45/6=7.5\) m/s.  
At \(t=4\): \(v(4)=-6<0\) (moving negative), \(a(4)=3>0\) (decelerating at that instant).

---

## Q2  (parameter from \(a(2)\); distance in 3rd second; average speed)
A particle passes through \(O\) at \(t=0\). Its velocity is
\[
v=6t^2-pt.
\]
Given that when \(t=2\), the acceleration is \(20\) m/s\(^2\).  
(i) Find \(p\).  
(ii) Find the velocity when the acceleration is zero.  
(iii) Find the distance travelled in the **third second**.  
(iv) Find the average speed in the first \(3\) seconds.

**Solution:**  
\(a=12t-p\). At \(t=2\): \(24-p=20\Rightarrow p=4\).  
So \(v=2t(3t-2)\). When \(a=0\Rightarrow t=\frac13\), velocity \(v=-\frac23\) m/s.  
Third second: \(\int_2^3(6t^2-4t)\,dt=28\) m.  
\(s=2t^3-2t^2\). Turning at \(t=\frac23\). Total distance \(=\frac{988}{27}\) m, average speed \(=\frac{988}{81}\approx12.20\) m/s.

---

## Q3  (trig \(v\); first rest; distance + average speed)
A particle starts at \(t=0\) from a point whose displacement from \(O\) is \(2\) m. Its velocity is
\[
v=2\sin t+3\cos t.
\]
(i) Find \(a\) and \(s\).  
(ii) Find the first time the particle is instantaneously at rest.  
(iii) Find the acceleration when \(t=\frac{\pi}{4}\).  
(iv) Find the total distance travelled in the first \(3\) seconds and hence the average speed.

**Solution:**  
\(a=2\cos t-3\sin t\).  
\(s=-2\cos t+3\sin t+4\) (since \(s(0)=2\)).  
Rest when \(\tan t=-\frac32\Rightarrow t=\pi-\tan^{-1}\!\frac32\).  
\(a(\pi/4)=2\frac{\sqrt2}{2}-3\frac{\sqrt2}{2}=-\frac{\sqrt2}{2}\).  
Turning at \(t=\pi-\tan^{-1}\!\frac32\) gives \(s=\sqrt{13}+4\).  
Distance in first \(3\) s:
\[
2\sqrt{13}+2+2\cos 3-3\sin 3\approx 6.808\ \text{m},
\]
average speed \(\approx 2.269\) m/s.

---

## Q4  (exponential \(a\); reach rest point; show return in 8th second; average speed)
A particle passes through \(O\) at \(t=0\) with speed \(15\) m/s. Its acceleration is
\[
a=-10e^{-t/2},\qquad s(0)=0.
\]
It comes to rest at a point \(P\).  
(i) Show that the particle reaches \(P\) when \(t=4\ln 2\).  
(ii) Find \(OP\).  
(iii) Show that the particle is again at \(O\) at some instant during the **8th second** after first passing through \(O\).  
(iv) Find the average speed in the first \(8\) seconds.

**Solution:**  
\(v=\int a\,dt=20e^{-t/2}-5\). Rest: \(20e^{-t/2}=5\Rightarrow t=4\ln2\).  
\(s=40(1-e^{-t/2})-5t\Rightarrow OP=s(4\ln2)=30-20\ln2\approx16.14\) m.  
\(s(7)=5-40e^{-3.5}>0,\quad s(8)=-40e^{-4}<0\Rightarrow\) return in \((7,8)\).  
Distance in first 8 s \(=2OP+40e^{-4}=60-40\ln2+40e^{-4}\).  
Average speed \(=\dfrac{60-40\ln2+40e^{-4}}{8}=7.5-5\ln2+5e^{-4}\approx4.13\) m/s.

---

## Q5  (“use a sketch”; turn back; distance + average speed)
A particle passes through \(O\) and its displacement is
\[
s=16t-3t^2,\qquad 0\le t\le 6.
\]
(i) Sketch the graph of \(s\) against \(t\) for \(0\le t\le 6\).  
(ii) Use your sketch to estimate when the particle turns back, and when it next passes through \(O\).  
(iii) Find these times exactly.  
(iv) Find the total distance travelled in the first \(6\) seconds and hence the average speed.

**Solution:**  
\(v=16-6t\Rightarrow\) turn at \(t=\frac{8}{3}\).  
\(s=0\Rightarrow t=0,\frac{16}{3}\) (next pass at \(\frac{16}{3}\)).  
\(s(8/3)=\frac{64}{3}\), \(s(6)=-12\).  
Distance in first 6 s \(=\frac{64}{3}+\frac{64}{3}+12=\frac{164}{3}\) m.  
Average speed \(=\frac{164/3}{6}=\frac{82}{9}\approx 9.11\) m/s.

---

## Q6  (R-formula; displacement vs distance; average speed)
A particle’s displacement from \(O\) is
\[
s=4\cos t+3\sin t.
\]
(i) Using the R-formula, write \(s\) in the form \(s=R\sin(t+\alpha)\), where \(\alpha\) is a positive acute angle.  
(ii) Find the displacement when \(t=\frac{3\pi}{2}\).  
(iii) Find the distance travelled when \(t=\frac{3\pi}{2}\).  
(iv) Find the average speed for \(0\le t\le \frac{3\pi}{2}\).  
(v) Explain briefly why the answers to (ii) and (iii) differ.

**Solution:**  
\(R=5,\ \alpha=\tan^{-1}\!\frac{4}{3}\), so \(s=5\sin(t+\alpha)\).  
\(s(3\pi/2)=-3\).  
Turning points when \(v=-4\sin t+3\cos t=0\Rightarrow\tan t=\frac34\), giving max \(s=5\), min \(s=-5\) within interval.  
Distance \(= (5-4) + (5-(-5)) +((-3)-(-5))=1+10+2=13\) m.  
Average speed \(=\dfrac{13}{3\pi/2}=\dfrac{26}{3\pi}\approx2.76\) m/s.  
Difference: displacement uses only final position; distance accumulates the whole path including reversals.

---

## Q7  (multi-particle; 3 meetings; average speeds)
Two particles \(P\) and \(Q\) move along the same straight line with displacements from \(O\)
\[
s_P=t^3-9t^2+24t,\qquad s_Q=6t,\qquad t\ge0.
\]
(i) Find all times when \(P\) and \(Q\) are at the same position.  
(ii) State the direction of motion of \(P\) at each meeting time \(t>0\).  
(iii) Find the total distance travelled by \(P\) in the first \(6\) seconds and hence its average speed.  
(iv) Find the average speed of \(Q\) in the first \(6\) seconds.

**Solution:**  
Meet when \(t^3-9t^2+18t=t(t-3)(t-6)=0\Rightarrow t=0,3,6\).  
\(v_P=3(t-2)(t-4)\): at \(t=3\), \(v_P=-3\) (negative); at \(t=6\), \(v_P=24\) (positive).  
Turning at \(t=2,4\): \(s_P(2)=20,\ s_P(4)=16,\ s_P(6)=36\).  
Distance for \(P\): \(20+(20-16)+(36-16)=44\) m, average speed \(=44/6=22/3\approx7.33\) m/s.  
For \(Q\): distance \(=36\) m, average speed \(=6\) m/s.

---

## Q8  (multi-particle from two points; two meetings; average speeds)
Points \(A\) and \(B\) are \(18\) m apart. Take direction \(A\to B\) as positive.  
Particle \(P\) starts from \(A\) at \(t=0\) with velocity \(v_P=6-t\).  
Particle \(Q\) starts from \(B\) at \(t=0\) with velocity \(v_Q=-3+t\).  
(i) Find the times when they meet.  
(ii) Find the position of each meeting point measured from \(A\).  
(iii) Find the speed of each particle at the first meeting.  
(iv) Find the average speed of each particle in the first \(6\) seconds.

**Solution:**  
\(s_P=6t-\frac12 t^2\). \(s_Q=18-3t+\frac12 t^2\).  
Meet: \(6t-\frac12 t^2=18-3t+\frac12 t^2\Rightarrow t^2-9t+18=0\Rightarrow t=3,6\).  
Positions: at \(t=3\), \(s=13.5=\frac{27}{2}\) m; at \(t=6\), \(s=18\) m.  
Speeds at \(t=3\): \(v_P=3\), \(v_Q=0\).  
Average speed \(P:\ 18/6=3\) m/s.  
For \(Q\): distance \(=(18-13.5)+(18-13.5)=9\) m, average speed \(=9/6=1.5\) m/s.

---

## Q9  (multi-particle; each reverses; meeting later; average speeds)
Two particles pass through \(O\) at \(t=0\) with velocities
\[
v_P=5-t^2,\qquad v_Q=t^2-4t+1.
\]
(i) Find the times when each particle is instantaneously at rest.  
(ii) Find the first time after \(t=0\) when they are at the same position.  
(iii) Find the relative speed at that time.  
(iv) Find the average speed of each particle in the first \(3\) seconds.

**Solution:**  
\(P\): rest at \(t=\sqrt5\).  
\(Q\): rest at \(t=2\pm\sqrt3\).  
Displacements: \(s_P=5t-\frac13 t^3\), \(s_Q=\frac13 t^3-2t^2+t\).  
Set equal: \(t^2-3t-6=0\Rightarrow t=\frac{3+\sqrt{33}}{2}\approx4.372\) (first \(t>0\)).  
Relative speed there \(=11+\sqrt{33}\approx16.74\) m/s.  
Average speed \(P\) (0–3): distance \(=\frac{20}{3}\sqrt5-6\), so avg \(=\frac{20}{9}\sqrt5-2\approx2.97\) m/s.  
Average speed \(Q\) (0–3): distance \(=4\sqrt3-\frac23\), so avg \(=\frac{4}{3}\sqrt3-\frac{2}{9}\approx2.09\) m/s.

---

## Q10  (multi-particle; determine parameter; two further meetings; average speed)
Two particles start from \(O\) at \(t=0\). Their velocities are
\[
v_P=t^2-kt+4,\qquad v_Q=2t-1,
\]
and both have displacement \(0\) at \(t=0\). They are together again at \(t=3\).  
(i) Find \(k\).  
(ii) Find the other time \(t>0\) when they are together.  
(iii) Find the total distance travelled by \(P\) in the first \(5\) seconds.  
(iv) Find the average speed of \(Q\) in the first \(5\) seconds.

**Solution:**  
\(s_P=\frac13 t^3-\frac{k}{2}t^2+4t,\quad s_Q=t^2-t\).  
At \(t=3\): \(21-\frac{9k}{2}=6\Rightarrow k=\frac{10}{3}\).  
Then \(s_P-s_Q=\frac13 t(t-3)(t-5)\Rightarrow t=0,3,5\) so other time is \(t=5\).  
Since \(v_P\) has no real roots, it stays positive \(\Rightarrow\) distance in first 5 s is \(s_P(5)=20\) m.  
For \(Q\): turning at \(t=\frac12\); total distance in first 5 s \(=\frac14+\left(20+\frac14\right)=\frac{41}{2}\).  
Average speed \(=\frac{41/2}{5}=\frac{41}{10}=4.1\) m/s.

---

## Q11  (given \(a\); rest at two points \(A,B\); distance in 3rd second; average speed)
A particle passes through \(O\) at \(t=0\) with velocity \(12\) m/s. Its acceleration is
\[
a=2t-8.
\]
(i) Find \(v\) and \(s\).  
(ii) Find the times when the particle is at rest.  
(iii) The particle is at rest at points \(A\) and \(B\) (for \(t>0\)). Find the distance \(AB\).  
(iv) Find the distance travelled in the **third second**.  
(v) Find the average speed in the first \(6\) seconds.

**Solution:**  
\(v=t^2-8t+12=(t-2)(t-6)\).  
\(s=\frac13 t^3-4t^2+12t\).  
Rest at \(t=2,6\). Positions: \(s(2)=\frac{32}{3},\ s(6)=0\).  
So \(AB=\frac{32}{3}\) m.  
Third second (2 to 3): \(s(2)-s(3)=\frac{32}{3}-9=\frac{5}{3}\) m.  
Total distance 0–6: \(\frac{32}{3}+\frac{32}{3}=\frac{64}{3}\), average speed \(=\frac{64/3}{6}=\frac{32}{9}\approx3.56\) m/s.

---

## Q12  (given trig \(a\); greatest/least \(v\); range \(a<0\); total distance + average speed)
A particle has acceleration
\[
a=4\cos t,\qquad v(0)=1,\qquad s(0)=0.
\]
(i) Find \(v\) and \(s\).  
(ii) Find the greatest and least values of the velocity for \(0\le t\le 2\pi\), and when they occur.  
(iii) Find the range of values of \(t\) (in \(0\le t\le 2\pi\)) for which the acceleration is negative.  
(iv) Find the total distance travelled for \(0\le t\le 2\pi\) and hence the average speed.

**Solution:**  
\(v=4\sin t+1\), \(s=4-4\cos t+t\).  
Max \(v=5\) at \(t=\frac{\pi}{2}\); min \(v=-3\) at \(t=\frac{3\pi}{2}\).  
\(a<0\) for \(\frac{\pi}{2}<t<\frac{3\pi}{2}\).  
Rest when \(4\sin t+1=0\Rightarrow \sin t=-\frac14\). Let \(\gamma=\sin^{-1}\!\frac14\) (acute), so rest at \(t=\pi+\gamma\) and \(t=2\pi-\gamma\).  
Total distance over \(0\le t\le 2\pi\) is \(4\sqrt{15}+4\gamma\).  
Average speed \(=\dfrac{4\sqrt{15}+4\gamma}{2\pi}=\dfrac{2\sqrt{15}+2\gamma}{\pi}\approx2.63\) m/s.

---

## Q13  (given \(s\); “velocity when \(a=6\)”; minimum velocity; average speed)
A particle’s displacement from \(O\) is
\[
s=3t^3-18t^2+27t+4,\qquad t\ge0.
\]
(i) Find the distance \(OA\), where \(A\) is the position at \(t=0\).  
(ii) Find the acceleration when \(t=3\).  
(iii) Find the velocity when the acceleration is \(6\) m/s\(^2\).  
(iv) Find the minimum value of the velocity and when it occurs.  
(v) Find the range of values of \(t\) for which the acceleration is negative.  
(vi) Find the average speed in the first \(4\) seconds.

**Solution:**  
\(OA=s(0)=4\) m.  
\(v=9t^2-36t+27=9(t-1)(t-3)\), \(a=18t-36=18(t-2)\).  
\(a(3)=18\) m/s\(^2\).  
\(a=6\Rightarrow t=\frac{7}{3}\Rightarrow v=-8\) m/s.  
Minimum \(v\) at \(t=2\): \(v_{\min}=-9\) m/s.  
\(a<0\) for \(0\le t<2\).  
\(s(0)=4,\ s(1)=16,\ s(3)=4,\ s(4)=16\Rightarrow\) distance 0–4 is \(36\) m, average speed \(=36/4=9\) m/s.

---

## Q14  (distance in 4th second with turning inside; average speed)
A particle passes through \(O\) at \(t=0\) with velocity
\[
v=2t^2-9t+7.
\]
(i) Find \(s\) in terms of \(t\).  
(ii) Find the times when the particle is instantaneously at rest.  
(iii) Find the distance travelled in the **fourth second** (from \(t=3\) to \(t=4\)).  
(iv) Find the average speed in the first \(4\) seconds.

**Solution:**  
\(s=\frac{2}{3}t^3-\frac{9}{2}t^2+7t\) (since \(s(0)=0\)).  
Rest: \(2t^2-9t+7=0\Rightarrow t=1,\ \frac{7}{2}\).  
\(s(3)=-\frac{3}{2},\ s(7/2)=-\frac{49}{24},\ s(4)=-\frac{4}{3}\).  
Fourth second distance \(=\left(s(3)-s(7/2)\right)+\left(s(4)-s(7/2)\right)=\frac{5}{4}\) m.  
Total distance 0–4 is \(\frac{101}{12}\) m, average speed \(=\frac{101}{48}\approx2.10\) m/s.

---

## Q15  (multi-particle trig; R-formula; meetings; relative speed; average speed)
Two particles \(P\) and \(Q\) move on the same line with displacements
\[
x_P=6\cos 2t+8\sin 2t,\qquad x_Q=10\sin 2t.
\]
(i) Use the R-formula to write \(x_P\) in the form \(x_P=R\sin(2t+\alpha)\), where \(\alpha\) is a positive acute angle.  
(ii) Find the values of \(t\) for which \(x_P=x_Q\) in the interval \(0<t<\pi\).  
(iii) Find the relative speed at the first such time.  
(iv) Find the average speed of \(P\) for \(0\le t\le \pi\).

**Solution:**  
\(x_P=10\sin(2t+\alpha)\) where \(10\cos\alpha=8,\ 10\sin\alpha=6\Rightarrow \alpha=\tan^{-1}\!\frac{3}{4}\).  
Solve \(\sin(2t+\alpha)=\sin 2t\Rightarrow 2t+\alpha=\pi-2t\) (gives the solutions in \(0<t<\pi\)):  
\[
t=\frac{\pi-\alpha}{4},\qquad t=\frac{3\pi-\alpha}{4}.
\]
\(v_P=20\cos(2t+\alpha)\), \(v_Q=20\cos 2t\). At the first meeting, relative speed \(=4\sqrt{10}\) m/s.  
Over \(0\le t\le\pi\), \(2t+\alpha\) increases by \(2\pi\), so \(P\) completes one full cycle between \(-10\) and \(10\), total distance \(=40\) m, average speed \(=40/\pi\approx12.73\) m/s.

---

If you’d like, I can **pipe this new set into the same LaTeX template** as your Version 1 (fresh page for solutions, two columns, smaller font, and no absolute-value symbols in the *questions*).
